body:
Hi gpherguson, > How can I tell pythonbrew to ignore the test's results and continue on? Try something like this in your shell: 
$ pythonbrew install --force Python-2.6.6
> Also, I'm seeing the following tests skipped. I'm not sure which, if any, I should be worried about. Got some insight? I'm sorry, but I'm not sure too.

I triangulated the problem using my machine at home and my Linux box and decided that it's something in our DHCP or DNS at work keeping the socket tests from succeeding. I decided to use the --force flag for the entire install, and it appears to be fine.

Hello bcroq,
This issues fixed at version 0.6.2.
Thank you for reporting it.

I confirm this is fixed in 0.6.2.

Thanks

Hi, Thank you for the great suggestions. :) It is supported in version 0.6.5. 
pythonbrew install -f file:///path/to/Python-.tgz

pythonbrew install -f /path/to/Python-.tgz

I fixed this bug in 0.6.7.
Thanks for finding it! :)

"pybrew switch 2.5.5" does not work? like this: 
$ python -V
Python 2.6.6
$ pybrew switch 2.5.5
Switched to Python-2.5.5
$ python -V
Python 2.6.6
If you mean the above, it has been fixed in 0.6.9 release. BTW, I think symlink command is good idea. I'm planning to implement it.

Hi,
I cannot use multiple Python versions in the same time. I need 2.5 for some code (Zope related), 2.6 / 2.7 for others and 3.2 for testing. It's a pity to switch all the time :).

> BTW, I think symlink command is good idea.
> I'm planning to implement it.

Cool!

Hi, The pythonbrew has been updated. v0.7 now supports symlink command :). Example: 
$ pybrew symlink # Create symlinks to all installed pythons.
$ pybrew symlink -p 2.5.5 # Create a symlink to python2.5.5, like "py2.5.5"
$ pybrew symlink -r # Remove all symlinks.
The fix for this issue is included in 0.7 release.
Great! pythonbrew is now sweet :).

Hi, It seems like curl command failed. What will be the result of the following command? 
$ curl --head -skL http://www.python.org/ftp/python/2.5.5/Python-2.5.5.tgz
If you are using a proxy, the environment variable HTTP_proxy must be set.

```
% curl --head -skL http://www.python.org/ftp/python/2.5.5/Python-2.5.5.tgz

Server: Apache/2.2.16 (Debian)

ETag: "14f0006-b11962-47e7531b40f40"
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Content-Length: 11606370
Content-Type: application/x-tar
Content-Encoding: x-gzip
```

2- I tried `pythonbrew install --force 2.5.5`, and now I get this `TypeError`

I guess I will delete everything and reinstall pythonbrew.

From now on, The pythonbrew-install script accepts python 2.7.

Hi, The pythonbrew has been updated. v0.7.1 now supports the -b option on symlink command. The -b option can create a symbolic link to the specified script in bin directory. You can try it with the following command. :) 
$ pybrew symlink -b pip
It will create symlink like 'pip2.5.5'.
now supported.
Works great! Thanks.

Hi,
I fixed this issue and released as version 0.7.2.

Great job!
I can install python 2.6.6 on Mac OS X by pythonbrew 0.7.2. Thanks!
Thanks!
Yep, I will add it. ;)

I want to make sure that you want the following behavior? 
$ pybrew symlink -b hg -d 2.7.1
$ ls -l ~/.pythonbrew/bin
hg -> /Users/name/.pythonbrew/pythons/Python-2.7.1/bin/hg
Right :)

The pythonbrew has been updated. Symlink command now takes new -d option. In version 0.7.3, the -b option has been removed from "symlink" command. You can use new syntax instead of -b option. Like this: 
* until version 0.7.2
$ pybrew symlink -b pip

* version 0.7.3 or later
$ pybrew symlink pip
$ pybrew symlink pip -d 2.7.1
yeah! Very usable now. Thanks.
Great thanks!

I also did a fresh OS X Lion install and doing `pythonbrew install --force 2.7.2` worked for me. It still runs all the tests. You can see `tail -f` the build.log file to see if it installs with a failing test. Worst case scenario, if something really messes up, delete pythonbrew, update pythonbrew with the latest patches, or grab python sources from the site and install it that way.

Hi,
`venv` command does not have a way to detect Python installed without pythonbrew.

`venv` command is an intended feature to create a virtual environment using Python installed with pythonbrew.
`venv` uses `virtualenv` and `virtualenvwrapper`, but in many cases they are not installed in environment of `/usr/bin/python` and general user is not allowed to install them.

Please install Python-2.x(2.4 or higher) using pythonbrew and try again.
(If you have a better solution, please let me know)

Hi utahta,

I did get it working if I install another Python under `.pythonbrew`. I don't have anything to add for now, but I'll be sure to let you know when I do.

Thanks (for the answer & the writing module) :)!

This shouldn't be too much of an issue.  It looks like most of pythonbrew is written in python, with the exception of the install script and the bashrc file.  It also looks like Virtualenv and virtualenv wrapper should support other shells too.

Is there anything that is currently broken when using /bin/sh instead of bash?

EDIT: It looks like there are some places in the installer functions where the shebang lines are hardcoded as: `#!/usr/bin/env bash` too

So, I took some time today to look at this.  The VenvCommand class does some funny stuff that essentially changes a template for the `venv.run` script, and then writes to it.

However, I can't seem to find where exactly the venv.run script or `workon` is executed.  I've got a couple questions:
- How does this currently work?
- What is the rationale behind using the `venv.run` script?
- Do you have any ideas on how to best implement the venv functionality ( maybe also other functions that a normal user should be able to do with pythonbrew ) so it will work in 'userspace' for a systemwide install?

> Systemwide install does not manage permissions well with virtualenv's

Yes, you're right.
I'm not implement/test systemwide install yet.
I will implement a systemwide multi-user system in the near future.

> Misleading error returned

It's not good, so I will correct it. Thanks for the mention!

> How does this currently work?
> What is the rationale behind using the venv.run script?

The venv.run script is run in bashrc (~/.pythonbrew/etc/[bashrc](https://github.com/utahta/pythonbrew/blob/master/pythonbrew/etc/bashrc#L64)).
It's because I can't change my shell's environment from a child process (such as Python's VenvCommand).
(the `workon environment_name`(virtualenvwrapper's command) affects the current shell)

> Do you have any ideas on how to best implement the venv functionality ( maybe also other functions that a normal user should be able to do with pythonbrew ) so it will work in 'userspace' for a systemwide install?

I'm considering best implement the venv functionality.
I think this will take some time...

Thanks :)

> Create isolated python environments (uses virtualenv):
> 
> ```
> pythonbrew venv init
> pythonbrew venv create proj
> pythonbrew venv list
> pythonbrew venv use proj
> pythonbrew venv delete proj
> ```

For example

```
$ pythonbrew venv create heroku
Creating `heroku` environment into /Users/andrei/.pythonbrew/venvs/Python-2.7.2
Already using interpreter /Users/andrei/.pythonbrew/pythons/Python-2.7.2/bin/python
New python executable in /Users/andrei/.pythonbrew/venvs/Python-2.7.2/heroku/bin/python
Installing setuptools.............done.
Installing pip...............done.
```

It looks that installing python require the package included "dpkg-architecture".
So please try installing the package of "dpkg-dev".
"dpkg-dev" might be including "dpkg-architecture".

dpkg-architecture is provided by dpkg-dev, but that isn't what is causing this error. I'm facing this same issue. After having spent an hour trying to figure out what was going on, I've finally discovered the cause.

When pythonbrew installs a python distribution, it will do the following:
1) Download the tarball
2) Extract the tarball
3) Apply patches
4) Configure
5) Make
... etc

This error doesn't manifest until after everything is done and the setup.py is run, but it comes back to when the file is patched in step 3. 

The patch that is being applied to 2.6.5 is all/common/patch-setup.py.diff. If you examine this patch, you will note that although it makes use of "find_executable" it does not explicitly import the function.

If you examine another patch, all/python25/patch-setup.py.diff, you will note that "from distutils.spawn import find_executable" is provided at the top. It is this import that is not being patched for 2.6.5 that is causing this error with setup.
did you install all the header files?

pythonbrew install 3.2.1 yields 4 failed tests:
    test_ctypes test_dbm test_distutils test_platform

Same issue here.
Added info to a Gist here: https://gist.github.com/1618234

Obviously the test_platform is wrong.

```
        if sys.byteorder == 'little':
            self.assertEqual(res[2], 'i386')
        else:
            self.assertEqual(res[2], 'PowerPC')
```

The platform is listed as x86_64, so this is just a bad test.
The pythonbrew docs even show that this test is wrong.

```
It is possible to build a number of flavours of the universal binary build,
the default is a 32-bit only binary (i386 and ppc). The flavour can be
specified using the option ``--with-universal-archs=VALUE``. The following
values are available:
 * ``32-bit``:   ``ppc``, ``i386``
 * ``64-bit``:   ``ppc64``, ``x86_64``
 * ``all``:      ``ppc``, ``ppc64``, ``i386``, ``x86_64``
 * ``3-way``:    ``ppc``, ``i386`` and ``x86_64``
 * ``intel``:    ``i386``, ``x86_64``
```

There are also a few patches floating around the internet.
Here is one that explicitely fixes the test_platform error: http://mail.python.org/pipermail//python-checkins/2011-July/106590.html

and discussion on applying the patch here: http://bugs.python.org/issue12549

I get this to.
IMO this is a bad test. The pythonbrew docs themselves point to far more platforms than just ppc and i386 (the only 2 values the test accepts)

This is also confusing to me. Any update on this?

Turns out that on Ubuntu you have to run the following script:

```
sudo apt-get install build-essential
sudo apt-get install libncursesw5-dev
sudo apt-get install libreadline-gplv2-dev
sudo apt-get install libssl-dev
sudo apt-get install libgdbm-dev
sudo apt-get install libbz2-dev
sudo apt-get install libc6-dev
sudo apt-get install libsqlite3-dev
sudo apt-get install tk-dev
```

This gets all the dependencies that python uses to build itself. You can cherrypick them but for distribute zlib and bz2 (I'm not sure about bz2) are a must. **This should be specified in the docs.**

If python still doesn't recognize zlib and fails to install distribute try installing dpkg-dev as the python install script uses it to find out where libz.so is.

```
sudo apt-get install dpkg-dev
```

This should be fixed in 40e9550

Pythonbrew is not made for this purpose. Your solution is to either:
- Install both 2.7.3 and 3.2.3 and use them as part of PythonBrew at all times.
- Or delete /usr/bin/python and recreate the symlink to /usr/bin/python2

I run Arch x64, and have taken the 2nd option. It was a bad decision on Arch's part to move to Python 3 so soon when most popular modules (numpy, django, etc) don't provide v3 support.

I just wanted to point out that I took the shortcut and merely replaced `$PYTHON_PATH` with a path to the current pythonbrew library. The more elegant solution in the future would be to prepend the path with the current pythonbrew library so that Python checks that first before moving on to system library modules.

However this could also cause unintended side effects so it's up for discussion.

The pythonbrew code is pretty easily understandable, so you just need to check the source code for the [`switch` command](https://github.com/utahta/pythonbrew/blob/master/pythonbrew/commands/switch.py).

Using `pythonbrew switch` will add `~/.pythonbrew/bin`, `~/.pythonbrew/pythons/Python-3.2.3/bin` to your $PATH, as well as _override_ your $PYTHONPATH with `~/.pythonbrew/pythons/Python-3.2.3/lib`. Replace 3.2.3 with whichever Python version you switched to.

I use an up-to-date Ubuntu 11.10 system with Python 2.7.2. As far as I know I do not use Pythonbrew. However, I do use the argparse module and it does not accept arguments with spaces (as described on the Stack Overflow issue). Should utahta's fix have solved this issue? If yes, how can I obtain the fix? Shouldn't it automatically arrive in Ubuntu?

In my limited understanding of the Pythonbrew bug, it was limited to
Pythonbrew. Argparse should have no problems with spaces, and I've used it
a bunch. That said, if there are spaces in the actual arguments, I remember
that the arguments themselves will have to be delimited with quotes.

Specifically, if I was trying to execute a program _foo_ with arguments _bar
*, you can type *python_ _foo --bar_. Pythonbrew replaces the python
command with the shorthand argument py, and that's where the bug
happened; _pythonbrew
py foo --bar_ would lose the _bar_ argument.

Thanks! I used the second approach also, but with a script that can change the versions and then bring them back to stock.

I found a way to do this without having to set `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` permanently in your shell init files. Basically, you can use `LD_RUN_PATH` at build-time instead of `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` at run-time. This is good because pythonbrew could set `LD_RUN_PATH` while building Python, and then users would not have to do anything special to make the installed python work.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6377921/problems-compiling-python-3-2-and-2-7-using-pythonbrew/10455502#10455502
I traced the prompt into the virtualenv package. A simple `export VIRTUAL_ENV_DISABLE_PROMPT=1` disables this behavior.

I thought the 1.3 update had resolved this issue, but it seems I was wrong.

The problem has to do with a Makefile in the `Mac/PythonLauncher` directory of the source tarball:

``` bash
$ head -n 32 Python-2.7.3/Mac/PythonLauncher/Makefile.in | tail -n 4
install: Python\ Launcher.app
        test -d "$(DESTDIR)$(PYTHONAPPSDIR)" || mkdir -p "$(DESTDIR)$(PYTHONAPPSDIR)"
        -test -d "$(DESTDIR)$(PYTHONAPPSDIR)/Python Launcher.app" && rm -r "$(DESTDIR)$(PYTHONAPPSDIR)/Python Launcher.app"
        /bin/cp -r "Python Launcher.app" "$(DESTDIR)$(PYTHONAPPSDIR)"
```

More specifically, `$(DESTDIR)` is not properly set to the subdirectory within ~/.pythonbrew where the framework assets will be installed. This variable is passed as empty to `make` when it's called after the installation changes into the `Mac` subdirectory.

It seems like the makefile vars that are appended to $(DESTDIR) are incorrect in that they are absolute. More specifically, I'm talking about $(APPINSTALLDIR), $(PYTHONAPPSDIR) in <distro root>/Mac/Makefile.in and a host of other vars ( $(BINDIR) or $(LIBDIR), $(MANDIR), $(LIBDEST), etc) in the root Makefile (Makefile.pre.in)

$(DESTDIR) is prepended to all of them, without exception, so it should be set to an absolute path itself, allowing variations on that base path to occur without fear of an attempted overwrite.

If you instead use `LD_RUN_PATH='$ORIGIN/../lib'`, the installation won't be tied to a specific path.  `$ORIGIN` is the `PWD` of the running binary (see linked SO page)

**EDIT:** sadly venvs breaks because virtualenv copies the `python` binary (changing `$ORIGIN`), but does _not_ copy (or symlink) the library, so C/builtin dynamic modules in the venv end up linking to the system python ... ungood :-( ...

... IMO this is a bug to be fixed (in virtualenv?), but an easy workaround is to manually copy/symlink `libpythonX.Y.so*` into the lib/ dir of the venv ... or do something a little yucky looking like (note X.Y.Z):

`LD_RUN_PATH='$ORIGIN/../lib:$ORIGIN/../../../../pythons/Python-X.Y.Z/lib'`

... pick whatever is less nasty to you; both verified to work.

**EDIT:** see: https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv/issues/216#issuecomment-8568603
BTW, there's an easy workaround: `VIRTUALENV_USE_DISTRIBUTE=1 pythonbrew venv create FOO`

:+1: for this. I wasn't able to get ssl in 2.6.5 on ubuntu 12.04. I applied this pull as a patch to my ~/.pythonbrew and it worked great.

For anyone else with this problem, here's the exact steps I had to use:

```
$ wget https://github.com/utahta/pythonbrew/pull/86.diff
$ cd ./pythonbrew/scripts
$ patch -p1 < ~/86.diff
$ mv pythonbrew/patches/all/python26/patch-_ssl.c-for-ubuntu-oneiric-and-later.diff ~/.pythonbrew/patches/all/python26/
```

Hi 

Python3X has been installed although setuptools has not. Setuptools does not work with python3, you have to use distribute instead. 

First you need to correct the usage error: go to your .pythonbrew/pythons/Python-3X/bin/

and substitute the symbolic link "python" so that it points to .pythonbrew/pythons/Python-3.2/bin/python3

Install distribute: 

curl -O http://python-distribute.org/distribute_setup.py
python distribute_setup.py

install pip for your brew

curl https://raw.github.com/pypa/pip/master/contrib/get-pip.py | python

Cheers, 

R

All well and good, but what about people who don't want these things. The three reasons why this shouldn't be added:
- Excessive warning/failures.
- Not everyone needs or wants these.
- This tool automates the building/installation of python, but doesn't hold your hand. For example, it also doesn't tell you to install build utilities.

All in all, this seems a bit iffy and I don't think this sort of thing should be in the main pythonbrew. However it is open source, you're free to fork and add these features and put in a pull request or have your own version of pythonbrew.

There is a pythonbrew.sh in /etc/profile.d/ on my CentOS box after installing pythonbrew systemwide. Debian does not usually has it. But from [this line](https://github.com/utahta/pythonbrew/blob/master/pythonbrew/installer/pythonbrewinstaller.py#L83), it seems that if it exists,  the installer would put there anyway first (instead of /etc/profile).
Thanks for the help. There was a pythonbrew.sh in my /etc/profile.d/ folder. After deleting it the problem was gone.

`pythonbrew use 2.7.3` sets the pythonpath and some other environment variables only for the current session. For a set of persistent environment variables, you need to use `pythonbrew switch 2.7.3`. This command will change files in your ~/.pythonbrew/etc folder.

Same problem here. Apparently the mentioned patch does not apply any more. This is a conservative fix:

File: `~/.pythonbrew/scripts/installer/pythoninstaller.py`, line 339 (see [here](/utahta/pythonbrew/blob/master/pythonbrew/installer/pythoninstaller.py#L339))

replace:

``` python
    elif is_python27(version):
        patch_dir = PATH_PATCHES_MACOSX_PYTHON27
        self._add_patches_to_list(patch_dir, ['patch-Modules-posixmodule.diff'])
```

with:

``` python
    elif is_python27(version):
        if version != '2.7.5':
            patch_dir = PATH_PATCHES_MACOSX_PYTHON27
            self._add_patches_to_list(patch_dir, ['patch-Modules-posixmodule.diff'])
```

libbz2-dev libdb5.1-dev libexpat1-dev libncurses5-dev libreadline6-dev libssl-dev libsqlite3-dev libxml2-dev libxslt-dev 
```

For beginners like me, please let the pythonbrew install script AT LEAST warn users that these packages should be installed for full functionality.

Should we fork it and call it something like "pythonbrew2" ?

We will need some type of name that people can identify with, so that they know that we are maintaining this, but it is separate from utahas pythonbrew and will follow its own direction.

I don't know if we'd necessarily have to change the name. The installs would be disconnected from a forked repo, so there shouldn't be a danger of a user accidentally updating if they didn't intentionally choose to do so. The only technical issue would be the PyPI upload, but maybe utahta would be okay if we took that over, too. I'd say that if he's fine turning over maintainership, we keep the same name.

Otherwise, I vote for **pbr**. :wink: Just kidding, I don't have any good ideas for names.

It doesn't look like he's even active here anymore. Maybe forking and getting him to just put a link to the new version is the least we could ask him to do without any interruptions.

Plus we'll need to consider possibly rewriting it for Python 3 (far-off thought).

Although names aren't important, we have:

pythonbrew2
pybrew2
pybro??
pb2
pybr2

I'm leaning towards something where the name distinctly exists so that people can identify that it is from the previous project (and works, mostly).

Lets see if utaha responds (i'm not exactly sure how to connect with someone directly on GitHub)
We should probably skip anything with "2" in the name—what happens if we get up to v3.0? But we could work with the suggestions given otherwise.

Any suggestions?

Otherwise we could just move ahead with "pybrew" or the original name itself.

Hi, will someone submit this? I also experience same problem here

You need to install pip together with Python instead of Python alone.

So try this instead:

> pythonbrew uninstall 2.7.7
> pythonbrew install --configure="--with-zlib" 2.7.7
